nodes.text: Settler mortality during colonization affected whether Europeans settled; settlement choices shaped early institutions; early institutions persisted and thereby causally affect current income per capita

Premise: Europeans adopted different colonization strategies producing either extractive institutions (limited property rights, high expropriation risk) or settler institutions (strong property rights and checks on government)
Premise: The feasibility of European settlement was strongly influenced by the disease environment; high settler mortality discouraged settlement and favored extractive regimes
Premise: Colonial institutions persisted after independence and influenced modern institutions
Method: Use historical estimates of European settler mortality (soldiers, bishops, sailors, 17th–19th centuries) as an instrumental variable for current institutions
Claim: There is a causal chain: log settler mortality -> fewer settlers -> worse early institutions (circa 1900) -> worse current institutions -> lower current GDP per capita

Evidence (first stage): Log settler mortality explains a large share of cross-country variation in current institutions (first-stage R2 about 0.25–0.30; mortality negatively predicts institutional quality and settlements)

Result (IV): Two-stage least-squares using log settler mortality as instrument yields a large, statistically significant effect of institutions on log GDP per capita (baseline 2SLS coeff around 0.9–1.1), implying substantial long-run income gains from improving institutions

Robustness: Results are stable to excluding Neo-Europes or Africa, to adding controls (latitude, colonizer identity, legal origin, religion, climate, natural resources, soil, ethnolinguistic fragmentation, current disease measures, percent European descent), and to alternative instruments (yellow fever exposure, settlements, early institutions)

Overidentification and exclusion tests: Using settlements and early-institutions measures as additional instruments produces no evidence that settler mortality has a direct effect on current GDP other than through institutions

Counterevidence addressed: Although malaria and yellow fever caused settler deaths, these diseases had limited direct persistent adverse effects on indigenous adult populations and current income; controlling for contemporary disease/health variables does not overturn IV results
Limitation: The analysis treats institutions largely as a black box; estimates show institutions matter but do not specify which concrete institutional reforms will causally produce improvements

Conclusion: Historical settler mortality provides a plausible exogenous source of variation in institutions; improving institutional quality is likely to produce large long-run increases in income per capita
